title-group.article-title: How Do Different Locations, Floors and Aspects Influence Indoor Radon Concentrations? An Empirical Study Using Neural Networks for a University Campus in Northwestern Turkey

abstract.p: Indoor radon (222Rn) concentrations were measured at a 10-min interval during October 2011 and January 2012. The monitoring followed a randomised and repeated pattern of experimental design, and was carried out at six faculty buildings of the Abant Izzet Baysal University, on five floor levels and two aspect directions (south vs. north) using an AlphaGUARD P30 Radon Monitor. The University campus area located in northwestern Turkey is near the North Anatolian Fault, a major active right lateral-moving strike-slip fault which runs along the transform boundary between the Eurasian Plate and the Anatolian Plate. Best artificial neural networks (ANNs) emulating indoor 222Rn levels were selected as a function of air temperature (Ta), air pressure (Pa), relative humidity (RH), Ta by RH interaction, local time, location, floor and aspect. Elevated levels of indoor 222Rn concentrations were measured at the south-facing offices and on the first floor levels of the building. Lower concentrations were found on the upper floor levels. Out of 27 ANNs, GFF-1-B-L and MLP-2-B-L performed best and could be contributing to the 35.6% and 87.2% of variations in spatio-temporal dynamics of indoor 222Rn levels as a function of location or floor level and aspect, respectively, in addition to Ta, Pa, RH, Ta by RH interaction and time.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Indoor radioactivity measurements have attracted much attention due to the human body exposure to radiation from natural, external (cosmic and terrestrial gamma rays) and internal (mainly radon) sources [1,2]. Radon (222Rn), formed from Radium (226Ra) as a decay product of Uranium (238U), can emanate radiation from rocks and soils [3]. Mean annual effective dose as a result of radon inhalation, and its short-lived progeny in air has been estimated to be 1.2 mSv per capita [4]. The dose of about 0.9 mSv from external sources can be further partitioned into 0.4 mSv due to cosmic radiation and 0.5 mSv due to terrestrial gamma radiation [5]. The remaining dose of 0.3 mSv originates from ingestion of potassium-40 in foods. Worldwide average annual effective dose from natural radiation sources was estimated at 2.4 mSv, one-third and two-thirds of which are from external and internal exposure, respectively [5,6]. Exposure to indoor 222Rn and its daughters is a well-known issue for human health in that long-term 222Rn inhalation in high concentrations could increase lung cancer risks [7]. Monitoring of indoor 222Rn levels in buildings, in particular, in nonventilated offices could play a crucial role in the understanding and interpretation of their spatio-temporal dynamics, thus enabling early mitigated measures to protect human health.

Various artificial neural networks (ANNs) have been developed to model outdoor 222Rn concentrations [8–11]. However, to the best of our knowledge about the related literature, there exist no studies that integrate the monitoring of indoor 222Rn in response to changes in air conditions, location, floor level, aspect direction and modelling of their spatio-temporal dynamics by ANNs. In the present study, the hypotheses we tested are as follows: (1) indoor 222Rn concentrations differ depending on changes in location, floor level and aspect direction, and (2) ANNs can be used to emulate spatio-temporal variations in indoor 222Rn levels as a function of air temperature (Ta), air pressure (Pa), relative humidity (RH), local time, location, floor level and aspect direction.

sec.title: Study Area
sec.p:
Bolu (30°32′–32°36′ E longitude, 40°06′–41°01′ N latitude) is located in northwestern Turkey at a mean altitude of 725 m. The Campus of Abant Izzet Baysal University (AIBU) in Bolu was chosen as the study area since the AIBU campus is near the North Anatolian Fault, a major active right lateral-moving strike-slip fault (Figure 1). The North Anatolian Fault is totally 1500 km in length, 140 km and 45 km of which were ruptured with the earthquakes (MW 7.4 and 7.2) on August 17, 1999 and November 12, 1999 [12]. Figure 1
The location of Abant Izzet Baysal University (Bolu) (designated by a rectangle near the North Anatolian Fault in Turkey.

sec.title: Radon Measurements
sec.p: Radon measurement was conducted using a portable radon monitor, AlphaGUARD P30 with a pulse-counting ionisation chamber (alpha spectroscopy) (Saphymo GmbH, Frankfurt, Germany) [13,14]. Factory calibration of the device whose stability was guaranteed for 5 years was performed using Saphymo’s professional calibration system with reference to National Radon Standards [PTG (FRG), NIST (USA) Ra-226, NPL (GB) Rn-222] of October 2011 prior to measurements. In addition, AlphaGuard, with integrated sensors, was used to simultaneously record such ancillary variables as ambient Ta, RH, Pa and local time. First, indoor 222Rn and ancillary variables were measured in three replicates at 10-min intervals during the period October 2011–January 2012, in the basements of six randomly selected faculty buildings: (1) Faculty of Arts and Science (FAS), (2) Faculty of Engineering and Architecture (FEA), (3) Faculty of Economics and Administrative Sciences (FEAS), (4) Faculty of Education (FE), (5) School of Physical Education and Sports (SPES) and (6) School of Foreign Languages (SFL). Second, variations in indoor 222Rn concentrations were studied as a function of floor levels (basement and floor levels one to four) and two aspect directions (south and north) at the Faculty of Arts and Science. In order to reduce (non)systematic errors and covariates, all the measurements were carried out under the same conditions such as nonventilated and nonsmoking offices; the size of the offices on different floors, the vertical alignment of offices on different floors, working hours between 8:00 AM and 5:00 PM, and the placement height (0.5 m) of the devices. For the determination of floor and aspect influences on indoor 222Rn concentrations, all the measurements were made during daytime and night-time.

sec.title: Statistical Data Analyses and Neural Networks
sec.p: Tukey’s multiple comparisons following a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) and two-way ANOVA were performed using Minitab 16.1 (Minitab Inc. State College, PA, USA), to determine significant mean differences between indoor 222Rn concentrations and ambient air conditions depending on locations, floor levels and aspect directions. General Linear Model (GLM) was used to perform the two-way ANOVA due to unbalanced observations for all possible combinations of the factor levels (five different floors and two aspect directions). A total of 27 ANNs was derived from a combination of 10 different topologies (generalised feed forward-GFF; linear regression-LR; multilayer perceptron-MLP; MLP with principal component analysis-PCA; probabilistic neural network-PNN; radial basis function-RBF; classification support vector machine-SVM; time-delay network-TDNN; recurrent network-RN; and time-lag recurrent network-TLRN), up to two hidden layers (1 vs. 2), two learning algorithms (Momentum-M vs. Levenberg-Marquardt-L) and two learning modes (batch-B vs. online-O). Two datasets were fed into a total of 27 ANNs to emulate 222Rn concentrations which included as input layers (1): Ta, Pa, RH, Ta*RH (an interaction term between Ta and RH), time and location; and (2) Ta, Pa, RH, Ta*RH, time, floor and aspect direction. The entire indoor 222Rn and ancillary dataset was randomly partitioned into training, cross-validation and independent validation datasets with the allocation order of 60%, 15% and 25%, respectively, for 27 ANNs. Accuracy performance metrics used for comparing ANNs were root mean square error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE) and coefficient of determination (r2). The ANNs were built using NeuroSolutions 6.01 (NeuroDimension, Inc. Gainesville, FL, USA),

sec.p:
All the mean values of indoor 222Rn, Ta, Pa and RH differed significantly from one another among the buildings of FAS, FEA and FEAS (p<0.001) (Table 1). Mean indoor 222Rn concentrations at the basements of the six faculty buildings ranged from 12.7 ± 8.2 Bq·m−3 at SFL to 23.5 ± 10.1 Bq·m−3 at FAS (Figure 2). Minimum and maximum concentrations of indoor 222Rn were both observed at 13:40 PM as 2 ± 3 Bq·m−3 at FEA and 47 ± 14 Bq·m−3 at FAS, respectively. sec.title: A Multiple Comparison of Floors and Aspects
sec.p: Two sets of measurements were carried out as a function of floor level (basement to fourth level) and the aspect direction (south vs. north) of the FAS building; which showed that the daytime versus night-time indoor 222Rn concentrations did not significantly differ much despite the mean highest and lowest values of 105 ± 46 Bq·m − 3 at 16:00 PM (n = 5) and 71 ± 37 Bq·m−3 at 20:00 PM (n = 14), respectively. The mean 222Rn concentrations at different floor level except for the fourth level were above the World Health Organization (WHO)-recommended limit of radon concentration of 40 Bq·m−3 regardless of aspect direction of the offices, but were below the reference level of 300 Bq·m−3 for lung cancer risk [15]. The mean indoor 222Rn concentrations at the lower floors were higher than that at the upper floors which support findings of De Francesco et al. (2011) [16]. The mean indoor 222Rn concentrations of 101.3 ± 19.9 at the basement and 93.2 ± 19.4 Bq·m−3 at the first floor were significantly higher than those of the other floors. The mean indoor 222Rn value of the north-facing offices (60.0 ± 24.9 Bq·m−3) was significantly lower than that of the south-facing offices (87.7 ± 31.4 Bq·m−3) (p<0.001). The fact that the basement underneath the south-facing front of the FAS building possesses deep cracks would most likely give rise to a greater diffusion of 222Rn into the south-facing offices than the north-facing ones. At the upper floor levels, the significant difference in 222Rn concentrations between the north- and south-facing offices diminished (Table 1).

The mean indoor 222Rn concentrations significantly correlated positively with Ta, Pa and with the change in aspect direction from north to south; but correlated negatively with the upper floor level (p<0.001) (Table 3). The ambient Ta correlated positively with Pa and with a change in aspect direction from north to south; but correlated negatively with RH and with the upper floor levels (p<0.001). The ambient Pa had negative and positive correlations with the upper floor levels and with the shift in aspect direction from north to south, respectively, whereas RH had a negative correlation with the aspect direction from north to south (p<0.001) (Table 3).

The Tukey’s multiple comparisons following a two-way ANOVA revealed that the aspect direction by floor interaction effect existed in the determination of indoor 222Rn concentrations of the FAS offices (p = 0.002). As can be seen from Figure 3, the presence of the interaction between the aspect direction and floor levels indicates that the indoor 222Rn concentration in a south- versus north-facing office could depend on the floor level. Parallel lines shown in Figure 3 mean that there was no interaction between the aspect direction and floor level, with a greater deviation of the lines, away from the parallel state, the higher the degree of interaction occurred between the floor level and aspect direction. Figure 3

Mean indoor 222Rn concentrations at different floors and aspect direction of the FAS building were found to be above the world average radon concentration of 40 Bq·m−3 except at the top floor. The WHO (2009) proposed a reference level of 100 Bq·m−3 to minimise health risks due to indoor 222Rn exposure [15]. Thus, the south-facing offices at the basement and first floor of the FAS building have indoor 222Rn concentrations slightly greater than the safe minimum standard by WHO [15] and below the action level (148 Bq·m−3) as recommended by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) [17]. Mean indoor 222Rn concentrations obtained in this study in the different faculty buildings and the different floor levels and aspect directions of the FAS building are in close agreement with mean indoor findings reported in the related literature [18,19]. Higher indoor 222Rn concentrations in the lower floors than the upper floors as found by this study are also supported by reports by Kerry [20] and Virk [21]. Geology is most likely one of the influencing factors for indoor radon levels as reported by Rafique et al. [22].

sec.title: Neural Network-Based Emulations of Spatio-Temporal Dynamics of Indoor 222Rn Depending on Location or Floor Level and Aspect Direction
sec.p:
The performance metrics derived from training, cross-validation and independent validation of the 27 ANNs indicated that GFF-1-B-L outperformed the other ANNs as a function of Ta, Pa, RH, Ta*RH, time and location (called plus location hereafter) (Table 4, Figure 4a). Likewise, MLP-2-B-L performed best among the other ANNs as a function of Ta, Pa, RH, Ta*RH, time, floor level and aspect direction (Table 5, Figure 4(b)). The predictive power of the ANNs in terms of r2 values based on independent validation ranged from 3.7% by RBF-1-B-M to 35.6% by GFF-1-B-L as a function of plus location and from 15.9% by RN-1-B-L to 87.2% by MLP-2-B-L as a function of plus floor and aspect direction. Independent validation-derived values of r2, RMSE and MAE pointed to GFF and MLP topologies as the best two ANNs regardless of the use of plus location or plus floor and aspect direction. Figure 4

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The present study is the first-of-its kind to combine a randomised experimental design and 27 ANNs in elucidating spatio-temporal dynamics of indoor 222Rn concentrations. Indoor 222Rn concentrations were found to vary in response to changes in locations at the six faculty buildings of the Abant Izzet Baysal University as well as the interaction effect of the two aspect directions (north and south) and the five different floor levels. In particular, RH, Ta and Pa specific to the six faculty buildings generated spatially different or similar values of indoor 222Rn concentrations. Spatial patterns of indoor 222Rn concentrations appeared to be closely coupled with aspect direction, floor level and their interaction. In emulating spatio-temporal dynamics of indoor 222Rn levels, the best ANN models of GFF-1-B-L and MLP-2-B-L accounted for 35.6% and 87.2% of variations as a function of location or floor level and aspect direction, respectively, in addition to Ta, Pa, RH, Ta by RH interaction and time.
